facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 177 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 14, 1963 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 14, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1962. C. Das Gupta and Sukumar Ghose, for appellants.

facts.text: High Court set aside acquittal of Ms. Baburally Sardar of Steward Hogg Market, Calcutta (appellant 1) and Abdul Razzak, partner (appellant 2).

anchor.surface_text: ment of the High Court of Calcutta setting aside the acquittal of M s. Baburally Sardar of Steward Hogg Market, Calcutta, appellant number 1 and of Abdul Razzak, a partner of that firm, appellant number 2, in respect of an offence under s. 16  1   a   i  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 read with S. 7  1  of that act.

facts.text: Offence under s.16(1)(a)(i) of Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 read with s.7(1).

anchor.surface_text: in respect of an offence under s. 16  1   a   i  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 read with S. 7  1  of that act. The facts which are number in dispute are briefly these On June 1, 1960 a Food Inspector of the Corporation of Calcutta visited the shop of the appellants.

facts.text: On June 1, 1960, Food Inspector of Corporation of Calcutta visited shop of appellants; Abdul Razzak was in charge.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number in dispute are briefly these On June 1, 1960 a Food Inspector of the Corporation of Calcutta visited the shop of the appellants. At that time Abdul Razzak was in charge.

facts.text: Food Inspector took samples of Comela Brand condensed milk from the shop, one sent to Public Analyst.

anchor.surface_text: He took samples of Comela Brand companydensed milk from the shop, one of which was sent to the Public Analyst. Upon an analysis made by the Public Analyst the milk fat companytent of the companydensed milk was found to be 3.4 which did number companyform to the prescribed standard in respect of companydensed milk.

facts.text: Public Analyst found milk fat content of condensed milk to be 3.4%, which did not conform to prescribed standard.

anchor.surface_text: Upon an analysis made by the Public Analyst the milk fat companytent of the companydensed milk was found to be 3.4 which did number companyform to the prescribed standard in respect of companydensed milk. A companyplaint was thereupon lodged against the firm before the Municipal Magistrate and Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta.

facts.text: Complaint lodged against the firm and five other persons including Abdul Razzak before Municipal Magistrate and Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint was thereupon lodged against the firm before the Municipal Magistrate and Additional Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta. Apart from the firm five other persons, including Abdul Razzak were also named as accused persons.

facts.text: Mohd. Yasin did not appear; represented as not mentally fit; counsel for Corporation gave him up.

anchor.surface_text: One of the accused persons, Mohd. Yasin did number appear but it was represented to the learned Magistrate that the person was number mentally fit. Thereupon the companynsel for the Corporation gave him up.

facts.text: Other accused persons pleaded not guilty and were acquitted by the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The other accused persons pleaded number guilty and were eventually acquitted by the Magistrate. Against that order an appeal was preferred before the High Court under s. 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to High Court under s.417 CrPC against Magistrate's acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order an appeal was preferred before the High Court under s. 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The High Court, however, allowed the appeal only against the appellants but dismissed it against the remaining accused persons.

facts.text: High Court allowed appeal only against appellants, dismissed against remaining accused.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, allowed the appeal only against the appellants but dismissed it against the remaining accused persons. The defence of the appellants was based upon s. 19 2  of the Act and was briefly this The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A.

facts.text: Appellants purchased tins of condensed milk on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under document Ex. A.

anchor.surface_text: The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A. At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk.

facts.text: Firm demanded warranty from Messrs. Choudhury Brothers but not furnished written; said warranty on each tin.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk. The appellants further pleaded that the tins were in the same companydition in which they were when they were purchased from Messrs Choudhury Brothers and that they had numberreason to believe that there was any alteration in their nature, substance or quality subsequent to the purchase of the tins.

facts.text: Tins were in same condition as purchased; no reason to believe alteration in nature, substance or quality.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants further pleaded that the tins were in the same companydition in which they were when they were purchased from Messrs Choudhury Brothers and that they had numberreason to believe that there was any alteration in their nature, substance or quality subsequent to the purchase of the tins. It may be mentioned that an attempt was made to secure the appearance of S. Choudhury of Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but it failed because he companyld number be traced at the address given in the cash memo.

facts.text: Attempt made to secure appearance of S. Choudhury but failed as could not be traced at address in cash memo.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that an attempt was made to secure the appearance of S. Choudhury of Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but it failed because he companyld number be traced at the address given in the cash memo. Section 16 1   a   i  of the Act, amongst other things, pro- vides that if any person, whether by himself or by any person on his behalf stores or sells any article of food in companytravention of any provisions of the Act or of the rules made thereunder he shall be punishable for the first offence with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year and or with fine which may extend to Rs. 2000 or both.

facts.text: Prescribed standard for condensed milk: at least 31% milk solids, at least 9% fat.

anchor.surface_text: It shall be free from preservatives other than sugar and companytain at least 31 per cent of milk solids of which at least 9 per cent shall be fat. As already stated, the Public Analyst found that the fat companytent of the companydensed milk was only 3.4 whereas the minimum prescribed in the Appendix is 9.

facts.text: Condensed milk stored by appellants was adulterated as fat content 3.4% below 9%.

anchor.surface_text: As already stated, the Public Analyst found that the fat companytent of the companydensed milk was only 3.4 whereas the minimum prescribed in the Appendix is 9. It is, therefore, clear that the companydensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated and, therefore, there was a breach of the provisions of S. 16 1  a   i  of the Act.

facts.text: Label on tins: Comela-Full Cream sweetened condensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Contents scientifically preserved, pure from healthy cows milk. Ideal for babies. Prepared by Kwality Diary.

anchor.surface_text: The companytents of the label upon which reliance is placed by him are as follows Comela-Full Cream sweetened companydensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Comela BrandThe companytents of the tin are scientifically preserved, pure and produced from healthy Cows milk. Comela full cream companydensed milk easily digestable and are ideal food for babies. Special care is taken to maintain freshness- Prepared by Kwality Diary.

facts.text: Cash memo specifies: 1 Case Comela Milk @ Rs.70/- Case, Amount Rs.70.00.

anchor.surface_text: As for the so-called cash memo it is sufficient to point out that all that it specifies is Quantity Description Rate Per Amount 1 C C Comela Milk C 70/-Case Rs. 70 00 There is number a whisper of any warranty on it.

facts.text: High Court convicted appellants under s.16(1)(a) and sentenced each to fine of Rs. 2,000.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, therefore, the High Court was right in setting aside the acquittal of the appellants and companyvicting them of the offence under S. 1 6  1   a  of the Act and sentencing them to pay fine of Rs. 2,000 each. The appeal is without merit and is dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is without merit and is dismissed. Bachawat, J. The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form.

facts.text: Defence under s.19(2) failed as no written warranty in prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: Bachawat, J. The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin companytainer gave a description of the article of food, but it did number give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

issues.text: Whether the condensed milk stored and sold by the appellants was adulterated under Section 2(i) of the PFA Act by falling below the prescribed standard of quality under A.11.07 of Appendix B to the Rules?

anchor.surface_text: A. 1 1.07 of Appendix B and runs thus Condensed milk means milk which has been concentrated from full cream milk by removal of part of its water with or without the addition of sugar, and includes the article commonly known as evaporated milk but does not include the article commonly known as dried milk or milk powder. It shall be free from preservatives other than sugar and contain at least 31 per cent of milk solids of which at least 9 per cent shall be fat. As already stated, the Public Analyst found that the fat content of the condensed milk was only 3.4 whereas the minimum prescribed in the Appendix is 9. It is, therefore, clear that the condensed milk stored by the appellants for sale was adulterated

issues.text: Whether the appellants committed an offence under Section 16(1)(a)(i) read with Section 7(1) of the PFA Act by storing for sale adulterated condensed milk?

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 1   a   i  of the Act, amongst other things, provides that if any person, whether by himself or by any person on his behalf stores or sells any article of food in contravention of any provisions of the Act or of the rules made thereunder he shall be punishable for the first offence with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year and or with fine which may extend to Rs. 2000 or both. Section 2 i  defines the word adulterated.

issues.text: Whether the defence under Section 19(2) of the PFA Act is available to the appellants?

anchor.surface_text: S. 19 1  it was not open to the appellants to contend that they were ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of the condensed milk sold by them. Subsection  2  of S. 19, however, furnishes a defence to a vendor ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of food sold by him provided he satisfies the requirements of that provision. Omitting the second proviso thereto, which is not relevant in the present case, sub-s.  2  of S. 19 reads thus A vendor shall not be deemed to have committed an offence if he proves- i  that the article of food was purchased by him as the same in nature, substance and quality as that demanded by the purchaser and with a written warranty in the prescribed form, if any, to the effect that it was of such nature, substance and quality that he had no reason to believe at the time when he sold it that the food was not of such nature, substance and quality and that he sold it in the same state as he purchased it

issues.text: Whether the appellants purchased the condensed milk with a written warranty in the prescribed form (Form VI-A) or equivalent under Rule 12-A?

anchor.surface_text: Rule 12-A provides that every trader selling an article of food to a vendor shall deliver to the vendor a warranty in form 6-A, if required to do so by the vendor. No such warranty was demanded by the appellants, not given by Messrs. S. Chaudhury Brothers. No doubt, under the proviso to the aforesaid sub-rule no warranty in the prescribed form is necessary if the label on the article of food or cash memo delivered by the trader to the vendor in respect of that article contains a warranty certifying that the food contained in the container or mentioned in the cash memo is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

issues.text: Whether the label on the tins or the cash memo constituted a valid warranty under the proviso to Rule 12-A for the purposes of Section 19(2)?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta for the appellants, says that the labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso and faintly suggested that the cash memo also satisfies the conditions. The contents of the label upon which reliance is placed by him are as follows Comela-Full Cream sweetened condensed milk made on formula of Holland Product. Comela BrandThe contents of the tin are scientifically preserved, pure and produced from healthy Cows milk. Comela full cream condensed milk easily digestable and are ideal food for babies. Special care is taken to maintain freshness- Prepared by Kwality Diary. This label contains no warranty of the kind referred to in the proviso. Moreover, it is not even in the form given for a label prescribed for Sweetened condensed milk. Under r. 42-B b  the label prescribed is as follows

arguments.claim: Defence under section 19(2) of the PFA Act is available as tins of condensed milk were purchased with warranty on each tin from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers, stored and sold in same condition, and no reason to believe any alteration in nature, substance or quality.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellants was based upon s. 19 2  of the Act and was briefly this The tins of companydensed milk were purchased by the firm on May 3, 1960 from Messrs S. Choudhury Brothers under a document of sale Ex. A. At that time the firm had demanded a warranty from the traders, that is, Messrs. Choudhury Brothers, but they did number furnish a written guarantee on the ground that a certificate and a warranty had been given on each tin of companydensed milk.

arguments.court_reasoning: No written warranty in prescribed form obtained; label provides description but not certification that food is same in nature, substance and quality as demanded; cash memo contains no warranty; failed to prove article conformed to prescribed standard.

arguments.claim: Labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso to Rule 12-A as a warranty, and cash memo also satisfies the conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta for the appellants, says that the labels on the tins satisfy the requirements of the proviso and faintly suggested that the cash memo also satisfies the companyditions. The companytents of the label upon which reliance is placed by him are as follows Comela-Full Cream sweetened companydensed milk made on formula of Holland Product.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ibed form. Rule 12-A provides that every trader selling an article of food to a vendor shall deliver to the vendor a warranty in form 6-A, if required

arguments.court_reasoning: Label contains no warranty certifying same nature, substance and quality as demanded; not even in prescribed form under r.42-B(b); full cream undefined and quantity unspecified prevents calculation of standards; cash memo specifies only quantity, description, rate, amount with no warranty.

arguments.claim: Condensed milk stored by appellants was adulterated as milk fat content found to be 3.4% which is below prescribed minimum of 9% under A.11.07 Appendix B.

anchor.surface_text: A. 1 1.07 of Appendix B and runs thus Condensed milk means milk which has been company- centrated from full cream milk by removal of part of its water with or without the addition of sugar, and includes the article companymonly known as evaporated milk but does number include the article companymonly known as dried milk or milk powder. It shall be free from preservatives other than sugar and companytain at least 31 per cent of milk solids of which at least 9 per cent shall be fat.

arguments.claim: Appellants committed offence under s.16(1)(a)(i) read with s.7(1) by storing adulterated condensed milk for sale.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 1   a   i  of the Act, amongst other things, pro- vides that if any person, whether by himself or by any person on his behalf stores or sells any article of food in companytravention of any provisions of the Act or of the rules made thereunder he shall be punishable for the first offence with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year and or with fine which may extend to Rs. 2000 or both. Section 2 i  defines the word adulterated.

arguments.claim: No defence of ignorance under s.19(1) available to appellants regarding nature, substance and quality of condensed milk.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the provisions of S. 19 1  it was number open to the appellants to companytend that they were ignorant of the nature, substance and quality of the companydensed milk sold by them.

arguments.claim: To avail defence under s.19(2), appellants must prove purchased article was same in nature, substance and quality as demanded (i.e., conforming to standard), but analysis shows it was inferior and not conforming.

anchor.surface_text: The aforesaid defence was available to the appellants provided that they showed, in the first place, that what was stored by them for sale to purchasers demanding companydensed milk was in fact milk which had been companycentrated from full cream milk so as to companyform to the standard of quality given in A. 1 1.07 of Appendix B.

arguments.claim: No warranty in prescribed Form VI-A under Rule 12-A was demanded by or given to appellants by Messrs. S. Chaudhury Brothers.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 12-A provides that every trader selling an article of food to a vendor shall deliver to the vendor a warranty in form 6-A, if required to do so by the vendor. No such warranty was demanded by the appellants, number given by Messrs. S. Chaudhury Brothers.

arguments.claim: Words 'Full Cream' on label do not satisfy legal requirements as 'full cream' undefined and quantity unspecified prevents verifying milk solids and fat standards.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Das Gupta strongly relied upon the words Full Cream and said that where companydensed milk is said to have been obtained from full cream the requirements of law must be deemed to have been satisfied. For one thing Full cream has numberhere been defined in the Act or the rules.

arguments.claim: Vendor accepting tins with such label had reason to believe it was not condensed milk of prescribed nature, substance and quality.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover, when a vendor accepts from the trader tins purported to be of companydensed milk bearing a label of this kind he cannot be said to have had numberreason to believe that it was number companydensed milk of the prescribed nature, substance and quality.

arguments.claim: Defence under s.19(2) fails as no proof of purchase with written warranty in prescribed form; label is mere description, not warranty certifying same as demanded by vendor.

anchor.surface_text: Bachawat, J. The defence under s. 19 2  of the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act, 1954 cannot succeed, as the appellants failed to prove that they purchased the articles of food with a written warranty in the prescribed form. The label on the tin companytainer gave a description of the article of food, but it did number give a warranty certifying that the food is the same in nature, substance and quality as demanded by the vendor.

holdings.text: The defence under s.19(2) of the PFA Act is not available to the appellants.

holdings.text: No written warranty in the prescribed form (Form VI-A under Rule 12-A) was demanded by or given to the appellants.
